H0.text: Gamma rays are produced by radioactive atoms, nuclear explosions, and stars.

H1.text: Plasma is the type of rays produced by radioactive atoms, nuclear explosions, and stars.

H2.text: Neutron rays are produced by radioactive atoms, nuclear explosions, and stars.

H3.text: Beta is the type of ray produced by radioactive atoms, nuclear explosions, and stars.

A4.text: A classic example is that of supernova SN 1987A, which emits an 'afterglow' of gamma-ray photons from the decay of newly made radioactive nickel-56 and cobalt-56.

A5.text: Gamma rays from radioactive decay are in the energy range from a few kiloelectronvolts (keV) to approximately 8 megaelectronvolts (MeV).
